title._content: The Sabina City Company $100 (one hundred dollars) municipal scrip

description._content: Title: The Sabina City Company $100 (one hundred dollars) municipal scrip County of Origin: Jefferson County Town of Issue: Sabine Currency Type: Municipal Scrip Denomination: $100.00 Bank Issuer: The Sabina City Company Imprint: None Date Issued: July 1, 1839 Notes: This municipal scrip was issued in Sabine by The Sabina City Company. Laid out in 1836 by Sam Houston and Philip A. Sublett, the city was first called City of Sabine. The name was changed to Sabine Pass in 1860. The left and right borders of the note are ornately decorated. The word ''REPUBLIC'' is printed at the bottom of the left border, and the words '' OF TEXAS.'' are printed in the lower right border. The number ''100'' is printed in the center of the left and right borders and is surrounded by decorative designs. The abbreviation ''No.'' is printed in the upper center of the note; the number ''1079'' is handwritten adjacent to it. Beneath is a vignette of an American Indian who is seated and overlooking a town or city with a star and rays overhead. The phrase ''THE SABINA CITY COMPANY'' is printed across the face of the note. The month, day, and last two digits of the year are handwritten on the note; the first two digits of the year, 18, are printed. It is signed on the recto by the secretary and president, both of whose signatures are illegible. Signatures: [illegible] sec. & pres. Dimensions: 9.5 x 21 cm.
